results.title: Egghub
results.overview: Egghub is a platform that connects organic egg buyers with local urban farmers that produce organic eggs. Buyers could search farmers based on their egg requirements. The idea is to let the app do the transaction while the farmers (or couriers) just drop the eggs in the buyer’s front door.

article.content: In the midst of the coronavirus pandemic that started in late 2019, the demands for locally farmed eggs are even higher than before. This means egg farmers will be in touch with their customers more frequently. While masks definitely helps, there has to be another way to make transaction safer and be more effective in preventing the virus spread.

Egghub is a platform that connects organic egg buyers with local urban farmers that produce organic eggs. Buyers could search farmers based on their egg requirements. The idea is to let the app do the transaction while the farmers (or couriers) just drop the eggs in the buyer’s front door.

article.label: Design process used in this case study

article.content: I began by interviewing several people with close ties to egg farming business and people who buy eggs on a weekly basis. The interview involves day to day egg business and general idea of what’s on their mind when buying and selling eggs. I created this persona based on these interviews.
Using story map, I explored several possible interactions for the app and what users could do on the app.
Satisfied with the story map, I continue with user flow model to finalize how the main flow would be on the app.
After the user flow has been finalized, I started to explore how the main process screens would look like using paper sketches.

Using the paper sketches, I started working on the lo-fi wireframes. I gather visual references from sources like dribble, behance, and several grocery shopping apps. With Adobe XD, I create the base components using Shopping UI Kit made by Emmanuel Ikechukwu. This would made the design process quick and easy.
I started adding brand colours and visual references on the lo-fi wireframes, resulting in final design. I do several steps of next iteration on this design.
After several steps of iterations on the final design, I made a clickable prototype on InVision for the future usability testing.
In this project, I learned about how to write a case study and think about my design process. I also learned more about using Adobe XD and InVision design tool.

For now, the project only covers the UI design from user interview to clickable prototype. I would like to do usability testing on the prototype and start another process to design the app from the farmer side.
Thank you for reading, here’s a little background

This case study is part of Diagramming and Prototyping course challenge from UC Berkeley Extension. It’s a challenge that covers the whole 8 week course. Some of the fellow classmates here are also UX field professionals in Bay Area. It was an incredible opportunity that lets me have a conversation about my design to these fellow classmates.

results.title: Improving Self-Service Laundry
results.overview: I frequent a coin self-service laundry (usually called laundromat in Bay Area) once every 2 weeks. There was this one time when I forgot to bring coins and cash. I have to get back to my house 3 blocks away to get them. Probably there’s more problem for laundromat users, or laundry in general?

article.content: I frequent a coin self-service laundry (usually called laundromat in Bay Area) once every 2 weeks. There was this one time when I forgot to bring coins and cash. I have to get back to my house 3 blocks away to get them. Probably there’s more problem for laundromat users, or laundry in general?
I decided to create a solution to my inconvenience.

article.label: Design process used in this case study

article.content: I began with user interviews to discover general problems about laundry. The interview was conducted inside self-service establishment and to users who had used other forms of self-service laundry. Because of this, the interviews showed more problems about self-service laundry.
These are common problems I found during the interviews.

list.content: Forgot to bring coins to coin laundromat
Credit card being stuck inside machine
Forgot that they had laundry going on for the whole day
Not enough washing and drying machine
Unattended laundry (or leftovers) inside machine, therefore unable to use machine

article.content: All participants I interviewed seems to fall into this type of persona.
After doing the research, I feel confident on defining the problems of self-service laundry.

Pain Point #1: Payment Problems
The payment problems ranges from forgetting to bring coins to credit cards getting stuck on machine.

Pain Point #2: Unattended Laundry Results on Time Wasting
One of the participants complains about seeing unattended laundry on every machine, causing them to not able to do laundry.

Pain Point #3: Forgetting Laundry
One of the participants completely forgot about their laundry for one full day.

Pain Point #4: Laundry being Taken Out Without Permission
One of the participants told me of one time when someone put their wet laundry on the floor.
I brainstormed several solutions to solve the pain points I defined earlier.

Solution #1: Payment App
This app could be used to store balance and get coins, in case users forgot their wallet. Users could use the app to scan QR codes in washers and dryers to do payment. They could also scan QR codes on coin machines to get quarter coins.

Solution #2: Laundry Alert System
Alert system will alert users of their impending laundry. The system could be an app, email, or text messages. This way, users won’t have to forget about their laundry.

Solution #3: Special Laundry Card
The special card solution is just another way of solving payment. The card can be used to store balances that could be used to pay laundry.
I explored the solutions more by sketching the Lo-Fi Wireframe of each solutions.
I spread an online survey between students of UC Berkeley, SurveySwap with USA as respondent residency, and Survey sharing 2019 group.

According to the survey, self-service laundry is still relevant to 73,1% of the survey participants. Participants also showed more interest towards payment app solution. With these research in mind, I moved on to prototype stage with the payment app solution.

I started the prototype stage with a co-design session with some designer friends. The goal of this session is to brainstorm the basic functions of the app. These are the proposed scenarios from the co-design session.
Here are the hi-fi wireframes based on the proposed scenarios and wireframe sketches.

list.content: Pain point addressed: Payment problems
Scan QR codes to do payment and get coins.
Save credit cards for future payments.
Pain point addressed: Laundry being taken out without permission
Locking will open or close whenever user scan the QR code.
Prevent anyone from taking out laundry without permission.
A penalty system for taking out the laundry for too long, so it’s fair for everyone.
Pain point addressed: Unattended laundry results on time wasting, forgetting laundry
Users will be alerted 5 minutes before their laundry is done.
The alerts would theoretically minimized unattended laundry.

article.content: Using the hi-fi wireframes, I started a usability testing to identify friction points.
From the usability testing I identified these friction points:

list.content: Penalty system were hard to notice at first glance
Active laundry list were too hidden
25¢ penalty per 5 minutes were too harsh

article.content: To answer these friction points, I have done steps that includes different font colors for penalty system, putting active laundry list in the homepage for easy access, and alleviate the penalty for a bit so it won’t punish the users with too harsh penalty.

article.label: Some participants felt 50¢ per 15 minutes is better when asked.

article.content: When working on this project, I realised more opportunities to test the app limit that I haven’t think of before, such as:

list.content: What if I put a loyalty program to reward users for keep using this app?
What if I could buy detergent using the app?

article.content: For this project to completely solve the laundry problem, there has to be more research and development for the laundry machine themselves. How the machines read the laundry requirements from the app? How the machines send signal to users phone to alert about their impending laundry? How do the locking mechanism works? An app for payment and tracking laundry won’t be complete without the laundry machines to connect with it.

results.title: Frienemies
results.overview: Ever heard of Bishi Bashi? The three of us, me, Dimas, and Chris decided to make our final thesis project a tribute for this game. Frienemies, to put plainly, means friends and enemies. To us, it means a friend who can be a rival. We felt it's the perfect title for the gameplay of this game where every player strives to be the very best.

role.name: DARUMA SPRINT Development, User Research, UI Design

article.content: Ever heard of Bishi Bashi? A good old party game that can made you destroy your precious controller? The three of us, me, Dimas, and Chris were having a blast playing this game. Each of us used to made this game a some kind of fun competition on saturday night with our respective friends.

article.label: Okay, not always saturday night. But you get my point.

article.content: Inspired, we decided to make our undergraduate final project a tribute for this game.

Frienemies, to put plainly, means friends and enemies. To us, it means friends who can be rivals. We felt it's the perfect title for the gameplay of this game where every player strives to be the very best (and occasionally beat some newbs while being at it).
Three of us done the user research and the overall UI design together. We develop one minigame each results in 3 minigames in total. I was responsible in developing DARUMA SPRINT minigame.

We started from user research phase. In this phase we use quantitative research by spreading online surveys to 79 participants who had played a party game. The purpose is to understand their preferences about some elements of the gameplay.
The purpose of this question is to decide the type of controls for our mini games. Most of the participants prefers using <strong>virtual buttons</strong.
The purpose of this question is to decide the overall duration of our mini games. About 48% of the participants prefer 60 seconds.
We observe three games with similar genre with Frienemies: Bishi Bashi, Mucho Party, and King of Party.

Bishi Bashi has 48 mini game available and can be played up to 8 players. There are also AI players for single play. Each mini game has a theme, use speed and precision to achieve scores higher than other players. This game is released for PlayStation 1.

Mucho Party has 3 free mini games and a total of 30 mini games if bought. Players must selfie and use their face as the avatar. There are 6 mode available to choose and 50 achievements. Players must use speed and precision to achieve highest score. This game is released for Android and iOS.

King of Party is an online party game that use Facebook for player connection. It has 4 default mini games and player can buy more using gem, a currency within the game. Players can also buy item for their custom avatar. It can be played up to 4 players. This game is released for Android and iOS.
From these research and observations, we decided to made Frienemies:

list.content: A mobile party game
Can be played up to 4 players
Cartoonish design
Using virtual buttons as control
Three mini games, each of us develop one
Each mini game with overall duration of 15 to 60 seconds

article.content: As for the mini games, these are the concept that was on our mind.

list.content: Tap rapidly kind of game
Bomb passing
Survival running with a Daruma

article.content: After the decision has been made, we sketch the wireframes to have a grasp of how Frienemies would look like.
Here's the end result of the project:
The first page of the game. Players can configure some settings first, or just directly play.

If players hit play button, this page is shown. Players who want to join must tap their respective avatar. There will be visual cue for ready players. The positions of the players here will be consistent with player control placements throughout the whole game.
Players can choose one from three mini games they want to play.

Developed by Chris. Players are given 15 seconds to tap their respective buttons. Each tap will increase their respective powers. Player with the most powers after 15 seconds have passed is the winner.

Developed by Dimas. Players must pass the bomb to the next player after tapping the bomb between one to three times. Tapping will decrease the countdown. Bomb will be passed between players clockwise. The first player to get the bomb is random. The countdown is also random ranging between 15 to 30. Player who had the bomb when the countdown turns zero gets eliminated. The last player standing is the winner.

Developed by me. Players must reach the white finish line to win. When moving forward, players must see the direction Daruma is facing. When Daruma faces the players, they must not move. Otherwise it's fine to move. If a player move when Daruma is facing them, they will explode and must start over. The time Daruma takes to face the players is random.
Shows information on how many win each player has.
Players can set sound and music volume here. There are also a choice to hide tutorial for each mini game.
Where we put our names. We wanted to get recognized. We also give credits here for the open source materials we are using for Frienemies.

Our original plan for Frienemies was to be played as a multiplayer online game. The reason it turns out to be a local multiplayer game was because we don't have much time and resources to develop the online multiplayer feature. We have plans for it, but the feature won't be available in the foreseeable future.

That being said, we were happy with how the game turns out and it was a fun experience developing the game. We got to learn how design and develop a mobile game from the ground up, and to finally publish it online.

results.title: ARD Design
results.overview: ARD Design is an architecture consultant company, based and founded in Jakarta, Indonesia, 1996. They had many collections of portfolio from their early years to present times.

article.content: ARD Design is an architecture consultant company, based and founded in Jakarta, Indonesia, 1996. They had many collections of portfolio from their early years to present times.
ARD already had a website that embodies their creative taste, with interactivity, animation, and smooth transition. The problem was, to achieve all those elements, the previous website used Flash.

The problem with Flash in this case that it requires loading until every content are loaded. Since ARD have a lot of projects inside their website, waiting became very long. And to be relevant at this time and age, they want it to be fast.
In short, they want to show their creative side and be fast.
To answer their need of a website that reflects their identity and with faster loading, I proposed to approach things from something simple. Their unique color palette from their logo.

article.label: The brown color was a bit different to draw more contrast from the logo

article.content: As for creative tastes, the people from ARD proposed using some of their already-made sketches.
Then, I started combining these elements, designing a prototype of the homepage using direct code.

The goal for showing the prototype is to see if the color palette goes well. I use the brown and orange combination for a nice contrast. As for the beige color, I got some difficulties on deciding where to put them. I decided that it would be best to use them as selection color.
Thankfully, they were satisfied with the combination. After I got the approval to move on, I continued designing the homepage and also started designing other pages.
Here's the end results of the project:
The first thing that most people will see. It has a collection of featured portfolios handpicked using a custom CMS. It is also where people could see the clients ARD Design had worked with.
The main piece of the website. It had every ARD Design's portfolios with three filter options.
This page shows the details. You can see the curated artworks of a project and the story behind it.
Where people can see the background and culture of ARD Design, as well as the people behind it.
Where ARD design can share their thoughts.
If you want to get in touch with the people at ARD Design, use this page.

A company website portfolio would be more usable with a backend side. I use AdminLTE control panel template for a quick and easy design process. Denis, the back-end developer, takes care of anything backend-side like database models.

article.alt: CMS dashboard, settings, project list, edit project

article.content: This is the first website project where I involved heavily on design. My design work here were done directly into code. For the next project, I would like to learn to design from wireframes and if possible, try to look into the research aspect of UX design.
You might also notice that many of the content on this project are still using lorem ipsum filler text. If you're interested on the copywriting gig, please contact me.
